thread.title: LSU preparing for new, 2:30 p.m. home game vs. S.C.
thread.title_full: LSU preparing for new, 2:30 p.m. home game vs. S.C.

title: LSU preparing for new, 2:30 p.m. home game vs. S.C.
text:
LSU preparing for new, 2:30 p.m. home game vs. S.C. GLENN GUILBEAU, Gannett Louisiana 8:39 p.m. CDT October 7, 2015 LSU's game Saturday against South Carolina has been moved to Baton Rouge due to flooding. (Photo: Gannett file photo) 
BATON ROUGE — Lagniappe game! 
LSU will become the first Southeastern Conference school since the 1970s to play more SEC home games than any other league school as its scheduled game at South Carolina on Saturday was moved on Wednesday to LSU on Saturday because of historic flooding in the Columbia, South Carolina, area. 
Kickoff is at 2:30 p.m. in Tiger Stadium. Television coverage information was not known as of Wednesday afternoon. 
“We have decided to move the game to Baton Rouge,” South Carolina president Harris Pastides said in a release Wednesday morning. “The stress on law enforcement and first responders is too great (to host the game at South Carolina). Moreover, we’ve had many in the Carolina family directly impacted by the flooding.” 
No. 5 LSU (4-0, 2-0 SEC) will now have five SEC home games and three on the road. South Carolina (2-3, 0-3 SEC) will have just three home games and five on the road. The Gamecocks’ only remaining home league games will be against Vanderbilt on Oct. 17 and against Florida on Nov. 14. The other 12 SEC teams have four league games at home and four on the road. 
“It’s an advantage,” said Ole Miss coach Hugh Freeze, whose 14th ranked team (4-1, 2-1 SEC) will host LSU on Nov. 21 in a game that could decide the SEC West race. 
“Of course, it’s an advantage for them to play five home games in the league,” Freeze said. “But when times of tragedy strike, you pitch in and you do what’s necessary to help through those times. And I think this is an example of that. I hate it for the South Carolina people, but any time tragedy hits, I know these coaches and I know the SEC office are going to do what’s best for the people.” 
It will not be a typical home game for LSU, however, at least from a financial standpoint. South Carolina will keep ticket and concession money while reimbursing LSU’s expenses to stage the game on short notice, according to an LSU release. LSU usually makes more than $3 million on a typical home football game. Because of the unique setup with South Carolina keeping a lot of gate money, the next LSU-South Carolina game scheduled for Tiger Stadium in 2020 will remain in Tiger Stadium. 
LSU will also try to truly “host” the game more than usual. LSU’s band, for example, plans on playing South Carolina’s fight song for the Gamecocks fans who find their way to the game as the South Carolina band will not be making the trip. Other hospitality related ideas are in the works. 
The American Red Cross will be collecting donations for flood victims in South Carolina at the entry gates to Tiger Stadium. 
South Carolina athletic director Ray Tanner thanked LSU President F. King Alexander and athletic director Joe Alleva for their “cooperation” and “flexibility” in assisting the game site switch. 
“Changing venues on such short notice is no easy task,” Tanner said. “On behalf of the South Carolina athletic department, our thoughts and prayers are with those who have suffered the loss of life and property during this tragic flood.” 
Tanner and Pastides considered sites near Columbia such as Charlotte, North Carolina; Atlanta; and Jacksonville, Florida, but none worked out. 
“We look forward to the challenge and competing against the Tigers in Baton Rouge on Saturday,” South Carolina coach Steve Spurrier said. “We want to do the right thing and do what is best for all concerned. It appears the best thing is to travel to LSU.” 
Spurrier has lost his last two games in Tiger Stadium as South Carolina’s coach — 23-21 in 2012 and 28-16 in 2007. LSU was a 13-point favorite to beat South Carolina before the venue change. That betting line is expected to rise five or six points because of the move. 
“We recognize and are very sympathetic that this is a very difficult time,” LSU coach Les Miles said on the SEC teleconference Wednesday morning shortly before the game was moved. “We want to support South Carolina in anything they want to do. We’ve been through weather issues here, and no one is above it.” 
LSU canceled its scheduled season opener against McNeese State on Sept. 5 due to weather. Miles’ first LSU team had to move its scheduled home game on Sept. 10, 2005, from Tiger Stadium to Tempe, Arizona, because the LSU campus was being used as the primary relief center for Hurricane Katrina, which had hit on August 29. 
“We’re hoping for their community and the entire state of South Carolina to get through this damage from the flood waters and what was the loss of life,” Miles said. TICKET, PARKING INFO 
LSU’s athletic department released the following ticket and parking information: 
TICKET INFORMATION 
Tickets previously issued for the game scheduled to be played in Williams-Brice Stadium in Columbia, South Carolina, will not be valid at Tiger Stadium. 
Tickets to the game will be sold in waves for the remainder of the week to the following members of the LSU fan base: 
Tiger Den Suite and Stadium Club LSU Season Ticket Holders LSU season ticket holders in premium areas can purchase their normal season ticket seat locations by logging in to their online season ticket account at www.LSUtix.net and completing the 2015 LSU vs. South Carolina Premium Seating Application under the Season Renewals option. The deadline to order premium seating is Thursday at 5 p.m. CT. 
Other LSU Season Ticket Holders Season ticket holders in those seating areas outside of the suites and clubs will be given an opportunity to purchase tickets based on their LSU Priority Point Ranking. Season ticket holders in this category are not guaranteed to receive their regular-season ticket seat location and are free to choose from available seats. The first wave will begin Wednesday afternoon (Time TBD) and subsequent waves will begin every hour throughout the afternoon. Season ticket holders in this category may purchase tickets once their time slot begins by logging in to their online season ticket account at www.LSUtix.net, clicking on “Buy Tickets”, then “Football”, then “South Carolina.” Season ticket holders in this category will be sent an email shortly listing when their wave begins. The deadline to order tickets in this manner is Thursday at 5 p.m. CT. 
LSU Students Beginning Wednesday afternoon full-time LSU students of the Baton Rouge campus will each be able to purchase one (1) ticket for the LSU student section by logging in to the online student ticket account at www.LSUsports.net/studenttickets. The student section will be confined to the North Endzone of Tiger Stadium and will be exclusively general admission seating (no reserved group seating for this game). Eligible students will be sent an email notifying them of when they can begin to purchase a ticket. The deadline for LSU students to purchase tickets is Thursday at 5 p.m. CT. 
General Public Tickets remaining in non-premium areas will go on sale to the general public on Thursday at 6 p.m. CT at www.LSUtix.net. 
All tickets will be emailed to purchasers as “Print at Home” tickets attached to the email in a PDF document. These tickets will need to be printed out on a regular laser printer by the purchaser prior to the game and brought to the game to be scanned at the gates, like any other ticket. 
South Carolina Ticket Prices Tiger Den Suite and Stadium Club -- $100 ($75 for the ticket and a $25 food/beverage fee)Lower Bowl Sideline and Upper Deck Chairback -- $75Lower Bowl Endzone -- $60Upper Deck Bench -- $40LSU Student Section -- $5 
All proceeds generated from ticket sales, minus the expenses that LSU incurs for hosting the game, will be given to South Carolina. 
PARKING INFORMATION 
Normal LSU Football GameDay parking policies and procedures will be in place for the South Carolina game. 
Season parking permit holders can use their Western Kentucky parking pass (grey pass, No. 5 in the parking booklet) to gain admission to their normal parking lot for the South Carolina game. 
Season permit holders are urged to retain their Western Kentucky pass following the South Carolina game, as it will be needed to park for that game on Oct. 24. 
Fans without a season parking permit can purchase game-by-game cash parking for $40 on the day of the game, or utilize any of the free parking areas outlined at www.LSUsports.net/parking. 
The American Red Cross will also be collecting donations at the gates of Tiger Stadium on Saturday for those victims of the flooding in South Carolina. 1 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://www.theadvertiser.com/story/sports/college/lsu/2015/10/07/lsu-preparing-new-230-pm-home-game-vs-sc/73526614/ TOP VIDEOS
